item.title: To Counter China’s Hold on Rare Minerals, Trump Turns to Australia
item.description: The United States hopes to become less dependent on China by increasing access to mineral-rich countries. Rare earth metals are vital to an array of modern industries.

item.title: White House Scrambles to Preserve Gaza Deal Amid Concerns About Netanyahu
item.description: The Trump administration strategy is to try to keep Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel from resuming an all-out assault against Hamas, U.S. officials said.

item.title: Gaza Humanitarian Foundation Operations Unravel
item.description: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation has suspended its aid operations because of the cease-fire, but it is also running low on funds and faces logistical obstacles to resuming its work.

item.title: How the Louvre Thieves Did It
item.description: My colleagues explain how the brazen daytime jewel heist at the Louvre happened and why.

item.title: How Jared Kushner Re-emerged at the Center of the Israel-Hamas Peace Deal
item.description: Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law, had a single goal: Get to a yes first, and hash out the details later. Tyler Pager, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, describes Mr. Kushner’s role in cease-fire negotiations between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: Senior German General Says Europe Must Do All It Can to Help Ukraine
item.description: European democracy and rule of law are at risk, the general says, so Europe must give Ukraine whatever it can to pressure Moscow, even if Trump does not.

item.title: The Indonesian Free-Food Program That Has Sickened Thousands
item.description: Indonesia’s president says the meals are improving nutrition in the country. Critics have called for a halt to the program, saying it threatens public health.

item.title: A Chinese Woman Builds a New Career in a Man’s World
item.description: An all-female repair business is challenging gender norms in China and catering to a growing population of single women seeking safety and comfort at home. We spoke to Ray Hou, who quit her office job to become a professional handywoman, about what motivated her to start a new career.

item.title: The Chinese Influencer Who Made a Career of Lying Flat
item.description: For many young Chinese, the relentless pressure to succeed has given way to a new minimalist lifestyle known as lying flat. We followed Tom Jia, a popular influencer who left his demanding job in Shenzhen to travel across China in search of the country’s most affordable — and least stressful — places to live.

item.title: In China’s Crowded Hospitals, She Found a New Career
item.description: As China’s population grows older, a new industry of gig workers is stepping in to help older patients navigate a complex, bureaucratic hospital system. We spent time with Jessica Wang, a 49-year-old mother from Beijing who found steady income and a renewed sense of purpose by becoming a professional hospital companion.

item.title: AI Data Centers Create Fury From Mexico to Ireland
item.description: As tech companies build data centers worldwide to advance artificial intelligence, vulnerable communities have been hit by blackouts and water shortages.

item.title: Amazon’s AWS Disruption Creates Outages for Hundreds of Websites for Hours
item.description: Amazon Web Services, a major provider of cloud services, cited a problem at its data center in Northern Virginia. The outage highlighted the fragility of global internet infrastructure.

item.title: What to Know About Diwali, the Hindu Festival of Lights
item.description: The biggest public holiday in India, Diwali features prayers for prosperity and good fortune — and lots of sweets.

item.title: Louvre Museum Remains Closed After Jewelry Robbery: What to Know
item.description: A stunning heist has raised uncomfortable questions about security at the Paris museum.

item.title: This Weekend’s Violence in Gaza Shows How Fragile the Cease-Fire Really Is
item.description: A round of violence on Sunday was short-lived, but analysts expect more tensions between Israel and Palestinian militants that will put the truce under strain.

item.title: In China, a Forbidden Question Looms: Who Leads After Xi?
item.description: Xi Jinping seems to believe that only his continued rule can secure China’s rise. But as he ages, choosing a successor will become riskier and more difficult.

item.title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Bolivia’s Presidential Election
item.description: Mr. Paz won the presidential election after promising gradual economic reforms, though many voters seemed more drawn to his divisive running mate.

item.title: Australia Could Be a Rare Earths Alternative to China for the U.S.
item.description: China’s escalating curbs on the critical minerals has given Australia, a longstanding U.S. ally, the opportunity to reposition itself to a transactional president.

item.title: Australia Says Chinese Fighter Jet Released Flares Near Its Military Plane
item.description: The incident in the South China Sea on Sunday highlights tension in a region where China is demonstrating its growing military capabilities.

item.title: Louvre Robbers Take ‘Priceless’ French Jewels
item.description: The robbers employed a portable electric ladder to break into a second-floor wing of the Paris museum that holds the French crown jewels.

item.title: Colombia’s Leader Accuses U.S. of Murder, Prompting Trump to Halt Aid
item.description: President Gustavo Petro said a U.S. strike in the Caribbean had killed a fisherman. President Trump said he would cut aid and impose new tariffs on Colombian imports.

item.title: Cargo Plane Slides Off Hong Kong Runway, Killing 2 Ground Crew
item.description: The Boeing 747-400, arriving from Dubai, skidded off the runway after landing and fell into the sea, Hong Kong officials said.

item.title: A Norwegian Who Shared Underwear With the Inuit and Found the Northwest Passage
item.description: Unlike the leader of the doomed Franklin expedition, Roald Amundsen delighted in getting to know and learning from the Inuit.

item.title: Canada Moves to Discourage Arctic Rivals as the Fabled Northwest Passage Opens Up
item.description: The Inuit of the far north helped solve the mystery of a doomed 19th-century expedition. Now Canada needs them to strengthen its claim to this newly contested region.

item.title: How Chile Embodies A.I.’s No-Win Politics
item.description: Political debates have flared across Chile over artificial intelligence. Should the nation pour billions into A.I. and risk public backlash, or risk being left behind?

item.title: ‘Everything Is Gone’: Gazans Return Home to Find Devastation and Little Hope
item.description: Residents who have gone back to the battered north of the territory after the cease-fire say it is a wasteland that will take years to rebuild.

item.title: Sanae Takaichi Is Set to Be Japan’s First Female Prime Minister. But Will She Advance Women’s Rights?
item.description: Sanae Takaichi is poised to break Japan’s political glass ceiling. But some worry she will maintain policies that have held women back.

item.title: The Contagious Gen Z Uprisings
item.description: It’s a good time to start paying attention to the youth-led protests that are spreading around the world and that have toppled governments.

item.title: Israel Strikes Gaza and Temporarily Halts Aid, Saying Hamas Broke Truce
item.description: Israel launched a wave of attacks on Gaza after accusing Palestinian militants of attacking its forces across cease-fire lines. Both sides say they are still committed to the truce.

item.title: Louvre Robbery: What Was Stolen
item.description: The stolen items include glittering royal tiaras, necklaces and earrings.

item.title: Gaza Aid Deliveries Struggle, Despite Cease-Fire
item.description: A single photograph of Palestinians besieging an aid convoy after the new cease-fire took hold in Gaza makes clear how much work lies ahead in the enclave.

item.title: A Fragile Cease-fire Between Afghanistan and Pakistan Ends Violence, for Now
item.description: The two committed to stop attacking each other after the worst outbreak of hostilities in years. But the underlying causes remain, analysts warn.

item.title: ‘Don’t Touch My Retirement!’ Wins the Day in France
item.description: The country’s attachment to an early pension, seen as a fundamental right, forced a major concession by the government, allowing it to survive, for now.

item.title: An Ode to October Baseball
item.description: With the World Series just days away, we look at the beauty of baseball — even if one team looks unbeatable.

item.title: Israeli Military Fires on Vehicle, Saying It Crossed Gaza Cease-Fire Line
item.description: Gaza’s rescue service said at least nine people, including several children, were killed in the strike in northern Gaza on Friday, underscoring the fragility of the week-old cease-fire.

item.title: The Spritzes and Carbonaras That Ate Italy
item.description: Tourism has turned some Italian streets into monochromatic eating zones. Some officials have banned the opening of new restaurants.

item.title: Large Fire Disrupts Flights at Bangladesh’s Main Airport
item.description: The blaze drew dozens of firefighting units, with military help. Officials said they could not yet specify what caused it.

item.title: 10 Injured in Balcony Collapse in Cincinnati
item.description: People gathered at a house near the University of Cincinnati tumbled to the ground from a third-floor balcony, fire officials said. One person was in critical condition

item.title: Venezuela Announces Sweeping Military Exercises as U.S. Escalates Pressure
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro this week called on civilians to help the country defend itself, while his defense minister warned citizens to “prepare for the worst.”

item.title: For Prince Andrew, a Steady Fall From Grace Ends in a Hard Landing
item.description: A parade of scandals tarnished the prince’s reputation, long before he gave up using his title as Duke of York on Friday.

item.title: Lithium Battery Fire Aboard Air China Flight Forces Emergency Landing
item.description: The battery spontaneously combusted while stored in a luggage in the overhead bin. The airline said there were no injuries.

item.title: Maps: Where the U.S. Is Building Up Military Force in the Caribbean
item.description: About 10,000 U.S. troops and dozens of military aircraft and ships are in the region as the Trump administration increases pressure on Venezuela.

item.title: Ukraine Braces for New Talks Without the Leverage of New Missiles
item.description: President Trump backed off selling Tomahawk missiles to Kyiv, opting instead for talks with Russia. Still, Ukraine’s negotiating position has strengthened since the summer.

item.title: Down Time
item.description: A lazy day during which we do absolutely nothing sounds heavenly, but how much unstructured time can we comfortably abide?

item.title: Ontario Psychologists Clash Over How Much Training Is Enough
item.description: Psychologists are pushing back against a proposal to cut their training requirements in a bid to license more providers.

item.title: The Kids Who Sued Trump Just Lost Big in Court. Or Did They?
item.description: A federal judge threw out their climate lawsuit against the president a few days ago. But legal experts say there was a silver lining in the judge’s opinion.

item.title: A Popular Afghan Singer Challenges the Taliban With Song
item.description: After living for decades in exile, chased by war and religious bans, Naghma persists in singing to her people.

item.title: Trump Backs Off Suggestion to Give Tomahawks to Ukraine, Again Deferring to Putin
item.description: At the White House, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made the case for why a weapons sale would help end the war. Mr. Trump at first seemed receptive, then expressed reservations.

item.title: Prince Andrew Surrenders Duke of York Title Amid Epstein Fallout
item.description: The royal’s fall from grace began nearly six years ago with a calamitous BBC television interview about his ties to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Madagascar’s President Was Ousted After Youth Protests. Now What?
item.description: The young people who toppled the government are now confronting questions about what’s next, and who will deliver on their demands.

item.title: Bessent Stakes Credibility and Taxpayer Money on Argentina Bet
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent’s multibillion-dollar bailout of a serial defaulter raises the specter of losses for the United States.

item.title: How a U.K. Spy Case Against China Abruptly Fell Apart
item.description: Evidence prepared for a collapsed espionage trial was published by an under-pressure government in Britain, offering a window into Western countries’ struggle to define Beijing as friend or foe.

item.title: Chevron Thrives in Venezuela Despite Threats by Trump
item.description: Chevron enjoys unusual sway in socialist-led Venezuela, positioning the energy colossus to gain from whatever comes of the crisis between Washington and Caracas.

item.title: Teresa Ulloa Ziáurriz, Rights Advocate Who Fought Sex Traffickers, Dies at 75
item.description: In Mexico, where the cult of machismo has long held sway, she waged a lonely, sometimes dangerous and often single-handed fight against prostitution and organized sex rings.

item.title: What to Know About Madagascar’s Government
item.description: After weeks of protests calling for him to resign, Madagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, seemed to have left the country, and the military said it had taken control. John Eligon, the Johannesburg bureau chief for The New York Times, explains what we know and don’t know.

item.title: Russia Jails Street Band for Performing Antiwar Songs
item.description: The group, called Stoptime, had been performing anti-Kremlin songs for months and gaining in popularity before the authorities moved against the open dissent.

item.title: Funeral Is Held for Raila Odinga, a Pillar of Kenya’s Democracy
item.description: Thousands paid their respects at a stadium in Nairobi. President William Ruto said the spirit of Mr. Odinga, who died at 80, “lives within every Kenyan and every African.”
